node.text: The fast-spreading #deltavariant is raising fresh health concerns even in places where Covid vaccination rates are high. Senior pharmaceuticals analyst Sam Fazeli is here to tell you what you need to know.

node.title: Your Biggest Delta Variant Questions Answered

node.text:
"Donald Trump upended the American presidency after stepping away from the company that made him rich and famous. Four years later, returning to his empire after losing the White House, what he finds may upend him," write Sophie Alexander and Max Abelson.

"Three quarters of Trump's net worth is tied up in urban real estate. And urban real estate has been hammered by Covid-19," Tim O'Brien tells @quicktake's Tim Stenovec.

The former president's net worth is down to $2.3 billion from $3 billion in 2016. The pandemic he promised would disappear is walloping his company, and the riot that got him impeached for a second time is wounding his brand.

Check out "Trump’s Ailing Empire" on bloomberg.com/graphics to see just how deep in peril he really is.

node.text:
It’s been 20 months since a pair of fatal crashes forced regulators around the globe to ground the once top-selling jet. The FAA finally approved the Max to resume commercial flights today, which will allow Boeing to make money off the roughly 450 Max jets it has built but not yet delivered.

After the longest grounding of an aircraft in modern U.S. history, it’s reasonable to ask whether the plane is safe. Bloomberg Opinion columnists Chris Bryant and Brooke Sutherland teamed up to discuss the future of the Max, and whether or not they'd be willing to board one.

#Boeing #Boeing737 #737max #airplane #aircraft #airline #southwest #americanair #flight #pandemic #livestream #video #igtv #travel

node.title: Boeing’s 737 Max Is Back. Are You Willing to Board?

node.text:
Frank Barry didn’t ask a soul about Donald Trump or Joe Biden on his @looking4lincoln trip. For the two months he spent crossing the country along the Lincoln Highway by Winnebago, talking with Americans and hoping to reach San Francisco by Election Day, he never brought up the campaign. Sometimes he knew how people felt — occasionally they would say, though usually not. But it didn’t matter. He wasn’t running a focus group. He was trying to catch glimpses of a more enduring spirit, the kind that has transcended parties and generations, the kind that lives, as Lincoln said, in the better angels of our nature. And maybe those glimpses could help us see more of ourselves in each other, and in the land we share.

#lincolnhighway #travel #rv #roadtrip #winnebago #highway #ontheroad #interview #video

node.title: The End of the Lincoln Highway

node.text:
“It was really impossible not to feel the immediacy, the urgency of climate change on this leg of the trip.”

Frank Barry stops in #Iowa and #Colorado, continuing his journey across the U.S. along the Lincoln Highway.

Video by @quicktake, footage by @looking4lincoln.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 03, 2021. May be an image of sky and text that says 'Flying is as sustainable asit's going to get in your lifetime BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
✈️The way some people are talking feels like the world is on the brink of a new, cleaner era of aviation. Unfortunately, the truth is that mitigating emissions from aircraft is one of the most challenging areas the world will face over the coming decades.

David Fickling explains: "In power generation, road transport, steel, chemicals and shipping, there are genuine breakthrough technologies such as wind, solar, batteries and green hydrogen which could sharply reduce or even eliminate carbon. Aviation’s best alternative technologies are far more incremental, and each have substantial barriers to adoption."

Take Sustainable Aviation Fuel, for example. It doesn't require much change to existing technology, but it's four or five times more expensive and growing enough biofuel on the world's existing agricultural land is a huge challenge. Plus, after all that, it probably wouldn't cut that much carbon. Once you account for processing and the effects of turning virgin land into farms, biofuel produced from Southeast Asian palm oil and U.S. corn often has a larger footprint than the fossil-based equivalent.

Unfortunately, there's only one sure way to cut aviation emissions. Stay off the plane. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 03, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'England'sso-called' so-called "Freedom Day" wasa total damp squib Greater London footfall U.K. footfall 0% change compared to pre-pandemic baseline -20 -40 Retail and recreation Public transport Source.GogleMoilityrReport.July26 -60 Workplaces Bloomberg'.

node.text:
England’s “Freedom Day” has been declared a damp squib. Even with hospitalizations and deaths low — and cases falling — mobility is plateauing and still below pre-pandemic levels in some areas. Brits are exercising their freedom to mingle selectively. The economic implications will matter for all governments trying to work out where society goes after Covid.

It’s the unevenness of Brits’ movement after an end to Covid curbs, rather than the overall level, that’s glaring. Public transport usage is only at 84%, despite road traffic being totally back to normal. Retail footfall is only at 75% of standard levels — suffering perhaps from a lack of office workers milling around in their lunchtimes. Credit and debit card spending is still 8% below February 2020 levels. Consumers are still hoarding: The savings ratio is at 20%, nearly three times the pre-pandemic level.

Lionel Laurent and Marcus Ashworth explain: “Some parts of this underwhelming activity may recover in time... But we should also take seriously the idea that something fundamental has shifted in the economy. Lockdowns have become habit-forming with businesses and consumers increasingly able to adapt to social distancing with smartphones, videoconferencing and e-commerce. For many people, the adjustment was so pleasant that they decided to drop everything to live elsewhere.”

The economic consequences could be huge. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 02, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'This 27-year-old Wharton grad went from intern to alleged criminal conspiracistir amatter amatterofyears BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
Meet Matthew Grimes, a 27-year-old Wharton graduate who works for Tom Barrack and was arrested with him on charges of acting as unregistered foreign agents for the United Arab Emirates.

It's not really core Money Stuff subject matter, but Matt Levine does want to spend a minute enjoying the headline, which is “From Intern to Co-Defendant.”

"That is really the dream career path," Levine writes: "You start out as an intern just making copies and getting coffee — 'aboard Barrack’s private planes, Grimes would graciously serve tea and crackers, and was sometimes called upon to book restaurant reservations' — but if you work hard and are a good team player you will rapidly progress. You’ll get face time with the boss, take on increasing responsibility, be put in front of clients, lead your own deals — Grimes 'was also president of a related special purpose acquisition vehicle.'"

If everything works out just right, you’ll end up charged in the same federal criminal prosecution as the boss. That’s how you know you’ve made it.

Tap the link in our bio to subscribe to Money Stuff, the one and only financial newsletter you'll ever need.

node.text:
The biggest question facing U.S. stock investors isn’t about the pandemic or economic growth or even inflation. It’s about whether the stock market can maintain its historically high valuation, a perch it has commanded for most of the past three decades.

"For about 120 years from the 1870s to the 1980s, the U.S. stock market reliably reverted to its long-term average valuation, and just as important, it spent roughly equal time above and below that average," writes Nir Kaissar.

"Since 1990, however, the market has rarely dipped below its long-term average valuation, the notable exception being the period around the 2008 financial crisis. Neither the dot-com bust in the early 2000s nor the Covid-induced sell-off last spring managed to subdue it," Kaissar continues.

The difference between the two periods is striking. Thus the conundrum: Is it safe to assume the market will revert to its long-term average valuation?

Tap the link in our bio to find out.

#reels #stocks #finance #stocks #stockmarket #data #finance

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion in London Tube. May be an image of ‎one or more people, footwear and ‎text that says '‎Londoners say they want $7,128 to go back into the office full time Swieguannsing + ب BloombergOpinion‎'‎‎.

node.text:
The popularity of WFH is highest among those who commute. Avoiding this journey was the most commonly cited reason in support of WFH in a recent survey by YouGov.

In 2019, the average one-way commute in London and the southeast of England was 45 minutes, with 18% of commuters enduring a trip of between one and two hours. For New York and New Jersey, the average commute was 54 minutes, with 27% commuting for one to two hours. This includes walk, wait and travel times.

Workers clearly feel emboldened to make a stand against losing something they see as valuable in WFH. A Locatee survey found that Londoners wanted 5,100 pounds ($7,128) to return to the office full time.

"It’s one thing to want to hold onto the savings from ditching the season during the pandemic, but quite another to demand a full-blown raise for working the same way you did in 2019," writes Chris Hughes.

But for employers, this cannot be a purely financial negotiation. It’s a strategic matter. Tap the link in our bio to read about how office power dynamics are changing around the world.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 01, 2021. May be an image of boots and text that says 'Whathappens whena brand gets adopted by haters? Dr. Martens found out the hardway. hard BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
Dr. Martens has evolved over the past 56 years from a German shoemaker favored by older women to a British icon and global brand. Unfortunately along this journey, Dr. Martens was also adopted by factions of neo-Nazis — so much so that, even today, the Southern Poverty Law Center lists the brand in its “Racist Skinhead Glossary.”

@benschott explains that Dr. Martens’ dilemma is that its core brand value is fans “subverting and twisting the boots and shoes to their own personal needs, attitudes and identity.” Dr. Martens is also proud of its association with skinheads — albeit only “multi-cultural, ska-loving skinheads.”

So how did Dr. Martens shed this unfortunate association? The answer has been to flood the zone by producing diverse products, promoting other tribes, and deploying euphemistic language.

But that's not the only way brands have dealt with hate-jacking. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 01, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
📈This cascade of disaster that we are living through is more than just bad luck; it has real and intertwined causes.

"We should not deceive ourselves into thinking of 2020 as a strange annus horribilis that abruptly brought all these evils into the world. The trends toward both a pandemic and a crisis of public order were visible well before last year," writes Niall Ferguson.

The global peace index shows that the rising trend of public protest can be traced back 10 years. The IEP estimates that what it calls “major unrest events” increased by 251% between 2011 and 2019.

There is a kind of feedback loop, whereby a major unrest event is associated with a 1-percentage-point reduction in GDP six quarters after the event. The IMF cites the yellow-vest protests in France in 2018 and the pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong a year later as examples of the process whereby unruly protests make a country’s economic situation significantly worse.

Tap the link in our bio to read why Ferguson believes we are living through a global "conflict avalanche."

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on July 31, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Isittime to stop obsessively counting every Covid case? BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
The impulse to count every case has become debilitating. It’s time to focus on a more informative set of data, writes Rachel Rosenthal.

Singapore’s data obsession has been one of its virtues throughout the pandemic. It’s easy to parse and you can almost set your clock to the government’s WhatsApp updates detailing the number of locally transmitted cases and imported ones.

But now there's an argument for focusing on the figures that really matter: vaccination rates, serious cases and deaths. 

If Singapore wants to go back to trying to live with the virus, it must interpret the data in ways that will make its people feel safe, not fearful.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on July 31, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Bad news: Pretty much every delicious thingis getting pricier Price increase Fewer Promotions Sports Drinks Trading Up Tea and coffee Fizzy drinks Milk Hot cereals Bread Water Beer Salty snacks Cookies -5 10 15 20% Source:IRI Consumer Ûackged Goods Demand BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
So it looks like we'll be paying for inflation then, with more expensive bread, beer and snacks. 😭

Consistent but modest inflation gets shoppers used to price rises. For grocers, when food prices are accelerating, they have to sell fewer cans of beans or loaves of bread to reach the same value of sales. So long as they keep volumes stable, sales automatically rise.

The problem is, the cost increases, not to mention rising labor expenses amid worker shortages on both sides of the Atlantic, are neither gradual nor consistent right now, writes @andrea_felsted.

Tap the link in our bio to read more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on July 31, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing, outdoors and text that says 'The pandemic has made going on vacation the opposite of relaxing BloombergOpinion Bloomber'.

node.text:
In 2010, Dutch researchers discovered that most people who go on holiday trips are no happier when they return.

Some of that has to do with working extra hard before the break in order to be able to take it, then extra hard afterward to catch up, and worrying in between about what’s happening in your inbox. But it also has to do with planning the trip, and fretting about things going wrong. Then Covid-19 came along and made everything so much worse.

Andreas Kluth speaks from experience. Just trying to figure out where he could go on holiday was hard enough: "At some point, every European country seemed to be doing its own thing, some keeping people out, others requiring quarantine exactly as long as the average vacation, and others yet welcoming everybody with proof of vaccination, negative tests or past infection. As to more exotic destinations, from non-EU Britain to the Americas and beyond, we stopped googling when we couldn’t even agree how to keep track of the various regulations and updates."

Tap the link in our bio to read more.

Flu vaccine rates in England and U.S. England U.S. Ages 65 and older Health care workers Ages 10 Ages 6 months to under 65 (at risk) Pregnant people Ages Ages 6 months to4 Ages 65 and older Ages Ages 13 17 Ages 50 64 Ages 25 I 50 Source:U.K.'sPublicHealth 75% BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
🌡️What happens when you layer flu on top of Covid-19?

"We don’t really know, since last winter saw an incredibly mild flu season, mostly due to measures such as lockdowns, social distancing and masking. Infections rates for flu were two-thirds lower than during the 2011-2012 season, which had record low rates," writes Therese Raphael.

We can’t count on a repeat. The low prevalence of flu last year makes it harder to predict which strains to include in this winter’s vaccine. We could get lucky again, or things could get worse: Lowered levels of natural immunity after a few low-flu seasons could make it easier for new variants to take hold.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about how we should prepare.
